page.title: 02ECOLOGY IN MALVERN WELLS
page.content: Land Use is dominated by the Severn plain and gently rising slopes to the east of the Malvern Hills.{Medium {sized fields}are hedged with thick well-maintained hawthorn and some oak and ash. Osier willow and poplar are more common on the{low lying poorly {drained areas.}Wide{roadside verges have nettle, wildflowers, stitchwort, vetches and trefoils. The{sheltered {cuttings}of a disused railway harbour wildlife less disturbed by agricultural activity.{Steep slopes below 250m on both sides of the Hills have mixed deciduous woodland (ash, oak, sycamore and sweet chestnut). The Hills Conservators have planted small groups of larch and silver birch on the west side.{Above 250m}grass grazed by sheep and rabbits has harebell, foxglove, gorse and bracken. Rose bay willow herb covers large areas.
